properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant early spring storm will bring rain and snow to much of New Brunswick on Wednesday. A low pressure system will intensify east of Cape Hatteras this evening and then move northeastward towards the Maritimes overnight tonight and Wednesday. Snow will begin Wednesday morning over southwestern New Brunswick and then spread quickly across the province by noon. The snow will likely mix with rain in the afternoon. Snowfall amounts of up to 10 cm are possible. Over southeastern regions of the province snowfall amounts in excess of 15 cm are possible and snowfall warnings have been issued there. Along the Fundy coast rainfall amounts near 25 mm are possible and rainfall warning are now in effect there. Northwestern New Brunswick will only receive light amounts of precipitation from this system. The precipitation will end Wednesday evening as the low tracks into the Gulf of St. Lawrence. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-02T15:35:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-02T07:36:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3113504685.2019
Area: Fredericton and Southern York County, Oromocto and Sunbury County, St. Stephen and Northern Charlotte County, Stanley - Doaktown - Blackville Area, Bathurst and Chaleur Region, Miramichi and area, Acadian Peninsula
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Alberta Emergency Alert - Telephone Service Disruption Alert Updated
properties.Summary:
Description: There was an incident that had affected telephone and cell phone communications in the area surrounding the Hamlet of Sangudo. All communication services have now been restored throughout the affected area. ### Severe damages occurred to the telephone and cell phone communication system in the area of the Hamlet of Sangudo, and a large service area surrounding the Hamlet. At this time, restoration of service to all affected areas has been restored. TELUS will continue to make more robust repairs over the next several weeks as required.
Expires: 2019-04-08T17:30:08-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Lac Ste. Anne County, 2019-04-01T17:29:13-06:00, NAADS-CA-AB-AEA1-5671
Area: Lac Ste. Anne County
properties.Author: Lac Ste. Anne County

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: ROAD DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR SMITHERS The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has continued a Road Dust Advisory for Smithers because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation or dust suppression. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. Exposure is particularly a concern for infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### Children, including teenagers, are at higher risk from outdoor air pollution because they often spend time being active outdoors. Young people are more likely to have asthma and their lungs are still developing. For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-04-02T19:39:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-04-02T11:40:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2676511586.2019
Area: Bulkley Valley and The Lakes - northwest including Smithers
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: DUST ADVISORY ISSUED FOR PRINCE GEORGE The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued a Dust Advisory for Prince George due to high concentrations of particulate matter (PM 2.5). This advisory remains in effect until further notice. Exposure to PM 2.5 is particularily a concern for infants, the elderly and those who have diabetes, and lung or heart disease. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions should postpone strenuous exercise near busy roads until the advisory is lifted. If you are experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, follow the advice of your health care provider. The City of Prince George’s Clean Air Bylaw prohibits all open burning, including backyard burning, and land clearing burning. During air quality advisories, this bylaw also prohibits street sweeping activties (unless approved by an Authorized Person), recreational fires, and use of wood-burning appliances (except for sole wood burning heat users). Industry is asked to reduce emissions wherever possible during the advisory. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at www.bcairquality.ca. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-04-02T18:10:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment, 2019-04-02T10:11:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4059623161.2019
Area: Prince George
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the B.C. Ministry of Environment

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major low pressure system will affect Eastern Quebec Wednesday and Thursday. It could give significant amounts of snow over the Gaspe Peninsula and the Lower North Shore, blowing snow and strong winds up to 100 kilometres per hour. Weather conditions should improve on Friday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-02T15:59:50-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, freezing rain and significant rainfall likely for Wednesday afternoon and Wednesday night. A low pressure system will intensify east of Cape Hatteras this evening and then move northeastward towards the Maritimes overnight tonight and Wednesday. Snow mixed with rain or freezing rain will likely spread across the Islands Wednesday afternoon then change to rain at times heavy Wednesday evening before ending after midnight. Total rainfall amounts in excess of 25 millimetres are possible. These amounts combined with the heavy rates of rainfall could lead to ponding and risk of localized flooding. The rain will be accompanied by strong and gusty southeasterly winds, shifting to strong northwesterly winds on Thursday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-02T15:44:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-02T07:45:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2490906497.2019
Area: Îles-de-la-Madeleine
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Les Suêtes Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A low pressure system will intensify east of Cape Hatteras this evening then track northeastward towards the Maritimes. The low will move across Nova Scotia late Wednesday to lie in the Gulf of St. Lawrence Wednesday evening. Very strong Les Suetes winds gusting up 160 km/h are forecast to develop Wednesday afternoon then diminish Wednesday night as the low moves into the Gulf of St. Lawrence. ### High winds may result in power outages and fallen tree branches. Les Suêtes wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-03T05:46:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-02T13:47:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1570878421.2019
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A low pressure system will intensify east of Cape Hatteras this evening then track northeastward towards the Maritimes. The low will move across Nova Scotia late Wednesday to lie in the Gulf of St. Lawrence Wednesday evening. East to southeasterly winds gusting up to 100 km/h are forecast to develop over portions of eastern Nova Scotia Wednesday afternoon as the low approaches. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-03T05:44:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-02T13:45:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2247382961.2019
Area: Halifax County - east of Porters Lake, Guysborough County, Richmond County, Inverness County - south of Mabou, Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County, Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A strong low pressure system will track north through Davis Strait today and tonight, and then weaken over Baffin Bay on Wednesday. It will bring 10 to 15 cm of snow to Qikiqtarjuaq, the heaviest of which will be this afternoon and evening. In addition, strong north winds this afternoon and evening will give near blizzard conditions as blowing snow reduces visibility. Conditions will start slowly improving overnight with a more rapid improvement Wednesday morning. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-03T00:32:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-02T08:33:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1178810243.2019
Area: Qikiqtarjuaq
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall, combined with melting snow, is expected. A low pressure system will intensify east of Cape Hatteras this evening and then move northeastward towards the Maritimes overnight tonight and Wednesday. Snow will begin early Wednesday morning and then change to rain later in the morning. The rain will taper to scattered showers late in the afternoon. Rainfall amounts of up to 25 mm are possible, especially along the Fundy Coast. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-03T05:39:36-00:00

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very strong wind gusts are expected or occurring Very strong southeasterly winds with gusts up to 140 km/h will develop near noon on Wednesday. Enhanced southeasterly winds will continue to increase Wednesday evening before diminishing to a strong southwesterly before Thursday morning. ### Very strong wind gusts can damage buildings, down trees and blow large vehicles off the road. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-03T05:12:34-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Snow and strong northwesterly winds with gusts up to 100 km/h will persist until mid morning. The strong winds combined with fresh snow will reduce visibilities in blowing snow today, with the worst conditions coinciding with the falling snow and strongest winds. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-02T19:59:59-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-02T08:14:59-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0918427156.2019
Area: Nain and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. A low pressure system will intensify east of Cape Hatteras this evening and then move northeastward towards the Maritimes overnight tonight and Wednesday. Snow will begin Wednesday morning over southwestern New Brunswick and then spread quickly across the province by noon. The snow will likely mix with rain in the afternoon. Snowfall amounts of up to 15 cm are possible. The precipitation will end Wednesday evening as the low tracks into the Gulf of St. Lawrence. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A low pressure system will intensify east of Cape Hatteras this evening then track northeastward towards the Maritimes. The low will move across Nova Scotia late Wednesday to lie in the Gulf of St. Lawrence Wednesday evening. Rain at times heavy will develop early Wednesday morning over southwestern Nova Scotia and quickly spread to the remainder of the province by Wednesday afternoon. The rain will be mixed with snow to start over parts of mainland Nova Scotia Wednesday morning. Over Cape Breton, the rain will likely be preceded by a period of snow over some areas. Rainfall amounts will be highest over Atlantic coastal regions of mainland Nova Scotia where 50 to 70 millimetres are forecast. Elsewhere, 25 to 40 millimetres of rain is forecast. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-03T05:44:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-02T13:45:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2740152033.2019

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard today, tonight, and Wednesday morning. A strong low pressure system will track northward through Davis Strait today and tonight and then weaken over Baffin Bay on Wednesday. Strong northwest winds have developed allowing visibilities to deteriorate to 400 metres early this morning. These blizzard conditions will likely worsen further by this evening as winds strengthen to 60 gusting 80 km/h. Conditions should begin to improve around midday Wednesday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-03T04:07:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-02T12:08:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3954737778.2019
Area: Clyde River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A low pressure system will intensify east of Cape Hatteras this evening then track northeastward towards the Maritimes. The low will move across Nova Scotia late Wednesday to lie in the Gulf of St. Lawrence Wednesday evening. Rain at times heavy mixed with snow will develop over Prince Edward Island Wednesday morning. Over Prince County, a period of snow is forecast before changing to rain mixed with snow. Rainfall amounts of near 25 millimetres are forecast by Wednesday evening. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
